cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications: price determination, market structure, decision making by individuals and firms, public policy. NOTE: extensive use of graphical and quantitative analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Microeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online asynchronous course.
The content is organized by week. Each week we will cover 2-3 separate topics.
We will not meet at a given lecture time, instead content will be posted for completion during the course of the week.
For each topic, you are expected to complete the readings, watch the videos, participate in topic discussions and, complete homework and assessments by their due dates.
You will have an opportunity to ask questions live during office hours, times TBD.
You must have access to a laptop or desktop computer with a strong, stable internet connection. A phone is not an acceptable substitute as some required components may not be accessible on smartphones. A camera and mic are required for online contact activities such as office hours. High speed broadband access (LAN, Cable or DSL) is highly recommended.
This course requires the use of computers, and of course, sometimes things can go wrong when using them. You are responsible for ensuring that you maintain regular backup copies of your files, use antivirus software (if using your own computer), and schedule enough time when completing an assessment to allow for delays due to technical difficulties. Computer viruses, crashed hard drives, broken printers, lost or corrupted files, incompatible file formats, faulty internet, and similar mishaps are common issues when using technology, and are not acceptable grounds for a deadline extension.

WW CHRM Certificate in Human Resources Management students are also eligible to enrol when course enrolment begins on March 2, 2020.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications: price determination, market structure, decision making by individuals and firms, public policy. NOTE: extensive use of graphical and quantitative analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Microeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Asynchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Section Added: April 5, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications from a macroeconomic (economy-wide) perspective. Topics covered include international trade and finance, role of money and the banking system, monetary and fiscal policy. Note: graphical and quantitative analysis are used extensively.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online asynchronous course.
Lectures in the first three weeks will be offered via Zoom on Mondays and Wednesdays 12-2pm (synchronous delivery), the recording will be posted afterwards.
Lectures in the last three weeks will only be recorded (asynchronous).
Tutorial material will be recorded as well as delivered online throughout the week. Several tutorial times during the week will be offered for students to choose from.
Tests and assignments will be done through a mix of Crowdmark and Quercus quizzes.
Students need a pdf reader and access to Crowdmark and Quercus.
For the tests students need to have internet access and the equipment to upload tests into Crowdmark within a limited timeframe. Students will get the opportunity to test uploading before the test.

WW CHRM Certificate in Human Resources Management students are also eligible to enrol when course enrolment begins on March 2, 2020.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications from a macroeconomic (economy-wide) perspective. Topics covered include international trade and finance, role of money and the banking system, monetary and fiscal policy. Note: graphical and quantitative analysis are used extensively.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
WW CHRM Certificate in Human Resources Management students are also eligible to enrol when course enrolment begins on March 2, 2020.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Hybrid – See Timetable Instructions
Section Added: April 22, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory of markets and prices. Determination of prices through the interaction of the basic economic units, the household as consumer and as supplier of inputs and the business firm as producer and as employer of inputs. The pricing system as the mechanism by which social decisions and allocation of goods are made in a market economy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Microeconomic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is a hybrid course.
The course meets bi-weekly Tuesday and Thursday 6-9pm EDT for a 2-3 hour lecture.
The lectures will be recorded and posted online for students who can't attend the live lectures.
Students are expected to have a frequent access to the internet, as all evaluations are conducted online and there are weekly evaluations.
All lectures and office hours are going to be held on Quercus and evaluations are going to be done with Crowdmark.

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory of output, employment and the price level; techniques for achieving economic stability; central banking and Canadian financial institutions and markets; foreign exchange markets and the exchange rate. This course is not intended for students enrolled in the BCom program; please see ECO209Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Macroeconomic Theory and Policy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online asynchronous course.  
There will be weekly videos for lectures (around 3-4 hours/week), and tutorials (1-1.5 hours/week), asynchronously.   
There will be synchronous office hours (around 2 hours a week) by the instructor to answer questions and clarifications about the lectures and the course content.  
There will be more synchronous and online office hours by the TAs. 
 The term tests and final exam will be written on-line using platforms like Quercus and Crowdmark, or other similar platforms.  
Overall, students need the ability to use UofT Quercus, Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra), Crowdmark, and a good internet connectivity to upload/download the course materials.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals more rigorously and more mathematically with the topics included in ECO200Y1and is intended primarily for students in certain Economics Specialist programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Microeconomic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 3 2hr online videos per week (two lectures and a tutorial) asynchronously.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class for half an hour from 11:30am-12pm on T and W (what would be the last half hour of normal class time) and on Th (I will work out the time with the TAs) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
The files will be provided in pdf and mp4 files, so the students don't need any special software to play them. We will use MS teams for the three weekly q and a sessions.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals more rigorously and more mathematically with the topics included in ECO202Y and is intended primarily for students in certain Economics Specialist programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Macroeconomic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is a hybrid course.
Lectures will be posted on Quercus and students can view them at their leisure. However, students will complete weekly online quizzes and problem sets during a specified time/window (TBD), and therefore must be available during class/tutorial time.
Multiple time windows may be offered if students are in different time zones. Furthermore, online office hours will be scheduled for specific times during the week.
Online tutorials will be available whereby the Teaching Assistant will discuss the answers.
Students will require a reliable internet connection to view lectures. To attend office hours, students will require reliable internet connection, a microphone and, preferably, a webcam. Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate Ultra will be used.

courses.name: Introduction to Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Asynchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Section Added: April 22, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Numerical and graphical data description; data collection and sampling; probability; sampling distributions; statistical inference; hypothesis testing and estimation; simple and multiple regression analysis (extensive coverage). Learn how to analyze data and how to correctly interpret and explain results. Use Excel to analyze a wide variety of data and replicate tables and figures in economics research papers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: GGR270H1, PSY201H1, PSY202H1, SOC300H1, STA220H1, STA221H1, STA247H1, STA248H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is online asynchronous: you have some flexibility in when you view lecture and tutorial recordings, when you participate in discussions, and when you complete graded work.
However, there are completion windows – including some that are relatively narrow (e.g. 12 hours on a particular date) – which means that you need to make yourself available regularly during business days when classes are in session and during the final assessment periods.
To complete this course online, the additional requirements are: have regular access to reliable high-speed internet and reliable electricity, regular access to a reliable laptop and/or desktop computer (either a PC or a mac are fine, a phone and/or a tablet is NOT sufficient ) that has a working microphone and webcam, Excel software, and the hardware, software, and knowledge to scan your handwritten work to be uploaded.
This course runs on local Toronto time.
Further details will be provided on the course outline.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course demonstrates how a rigorous application of microeconomic techniques can inform our responses to various environmental problems. Topics may include: air and water pollution and renewable resource management.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Economics and Policies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online asynchronous course.  
There will be weekly videos for lectures (around 3-4 hours/week), and tutorials (around 1 hours/week), asynchronously in some weeks.   
There will be synchronous office hours (around 2 hours a week) by the instructor to answer questions and clarifications about the lectures and the course content.  
There will be more synchronous and online office hours by the TAs. 
 The term tests and final exam will be written on-line using platforms like Quercus and Crowdmark, or other similar platforms.  
Overall, students need the ability to use UofT Quercus, Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra), Crowdmark, and a good internet connectivity to upload/download the course materials.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys important features of energy markets and related environmental challenges. One of the central objectives is to provide an understanding of the key economic tools needed to analyse these markets.  A related objective is the development of a framework for understanding the public discourse on energy and the environment.  Topics include the hydrocarbon economy (oil, natural gas and coal), electricity markets, global warming and other externalities, renewable energy, conservation, carbon taxes and ‘cap-and-trade’.
cmCourseInfo.title: Energy and the Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is delivered in a hybrid format, with synchronous lectures. 
The professor will make every effort to record and post the lectures. 
You must have access to a computer or a tablet with a reliable internet connection in order to participate, download and upload materials, watch posted videos and write tests at specified times.
An operating microphone on your device or headset is essential.
The required software is available to students through the University

cmCourseInfo.description: Focuses on the core ideas and concepts of game theory and on applications of them in economics and other social sciences. Topics may include oligopoly, electoral competition, the theory of public goods, voting theory, the free rider problem, repeated interaction, bargaining, evolutionary equilibrium, matching and auctions. Note: This course cannot be taken as a substitute in programs that require ECO326H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Game Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course.
Lectures will be given as 2 hrs/week webinar synchronously (Tuesday, Thursday 12-2 lectures, Monday tutorials).
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous 1-2 hrs/week online office hours (Date TBA) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
Additional asynchronous and recording material might be provided for the student to supplement what discussed in class.
Students will need a microphone, a webcam, a stable internet connection and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: The practical application of microeconomic theory to common legal problems: torts, contracts, property and crime, and the limitations of economic analysis. No previous familiarity with the law is assumed. (This is an economic analysis of legal issues, not a course in law.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Economic Analysis of Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 3hr online videos/week asynchronously.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
The plan is to have those office hours, 2hrs in the morning and 2hrs in the evening, to allow for the varied time zones the students will face.
Students need will Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: The practical application of microeconomic theory to common legal problems: torts, contracts, property and crime, and the limitations of economic analysis. No previous familiarity with the law is assumed. (This is an economic analysis of legal issues, not a course in law.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Economic Analysis of Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 3hr online videos/week asynchronously.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
The plan is to have those office hours, 2hrs in the morning and 2hrs in the evening, to allow for the varied time zones the students will face.
Students need will Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: A development of the microeconomic foundations of macroeconomic theory to expand students analytic skills by constructing and solving macroeconomic models. Topics may include: dynamic choice, neoclassical growth theory, uncertainty and rational expectations, business cycles, as well as fiscal and monetary policy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Economic Theory - Macro

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1hr/week (Monday 2-3pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content through Zoom meetings.

cmCourseInfo.description: Ample empirical and experimental evidence suggests significant departures from classical assumptions of economic behaviour. For example, humans are neither always perfectly rational nor always self interested. This course describes systematic ways in which behaviour deviates from neoclassical assumptions, generating new, and hopefully more realistic behavioural assumptions that have broad empirical, theoretical and policy implications.
cmCourseInfo.title: Behavioural and Experimental Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course will be an asynchronous online course.
Lectures will be posted as online videos, and students will have the chance to engage with the course material and each other through online discussion boards. While this allows some flexibility in when you complete your work, you will need to keep up to date with the course material, and be actively participating in the course on a regular basis, much like with a traditional course.
Students will need reliable Internet access via a computer with a working microphone.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the interaction of the monetary and banking sectors with financial markets and the broader economy. It builds especially on tools developed in intermediate macroeconomics, but also focuses on the institutional structure of the Canadian monetary sector, including the role and operation of the Bank of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Money, Banking and Financial Markets
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1, ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1, ECO220Y1/ECO227Y1/(STA220H1, STA255H1)/(STA237H1, STA238H1)/(STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This will be a hybrid course, where I will post an audio and PowerPoint lecture of the material ahead of class, where it is expected that the student would use the first hour of the 2 hour class to go over the audio lecture (Monday and Wednesdays, 2-3pm).
There will then be a synchronous audio and video lecture during the second hour (Monday and Wednesdays, 3-4pm), where I will go over key concepts, and take any questions students may have on the lecture material.
Tutorials will be announced later.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the interaction of the monetary and banking sectors with financial markets and the broader economy. It builds especially on tools developed in intermediate macroeconomics, but also focuses on the institutional structure of the Canadian monetary sector, including the role and operation of the Bank of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Money, Banking and Financial Markets
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1, ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1, ECO220Y1/ECO227Y1/(STA220H1, STA255H1)/(STA237H1, STA238H1)/(STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online hybrid course with both synchronous and asynchronous learning options. 

There will be regularly scheduled lectures online each week where students can ask questions about the lecture content. If they cannot attend these classes, there will be asynchronously opportunities to learn the course material including watching recorded lectures and participating in discussion groups online. 

Students will be able to complete course assessments at times that are flexible to suit their personal schedules and time zones. Students will need MS Word, Excel and PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard (Bb) Collaborate within Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economics of financial assets and financial markets. Topics: inter-temporal choice, expected utility theory, security valuation, selected asset pricing models, market efficiency, and the term structure of interest rates - essential materials for an understanding of the role and operation of financial markets.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Economics I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously, two times a week.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 2-3hrs/week (Wed and TH 10-12pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Agency and incomplete information problems inherent in financial transactions; the role of contractual arrangements in overcoming them. Financial constraints on investment decisions of firms; the financial system in economic growth; the legal system in the functioning of financial markets. A look at theoretical and empirical literature covering these issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Economics II: Corporate Finance

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously, two times a week.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 2-3hrs/week (Wed and TH 10-12pm) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Asynchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Section Added: April 22, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the causes and consequences of international trade. The first half develops traditional models of comparative advantage, with the second half examines more recent theoretical and empirical work on trade & wages, the political economy of trade, outsourcing, and firm heterogeneity.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Trade Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online asynchronous course.
Lectures will be delivered live using Blackboard Collaborate during the time periods mentioned in the course description.
However these lectures will be recorded and posted on the website so that students have the opportunity to watch recorded lectures if they cannot make the allotted time slot.
There will be no explicit penalty for not attending synchronous lectures. A similar approach will be used for tutorials.
All office hours will be done live using Blackboard Collaborate.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
Online Asynchronous – See Timetable Instructions
Section Added: April 22, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to open economy macroeconomics and international finance. The core objective of the course is to develop macroeconomic models of open economies that can be applied towards gaining an understanding of recent events such as US deficits, financial crises, China's exchange rate policy and the Euro.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Monetary Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is online, asynchronous

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to econometrics similar to ECO375H1, with greater focus on applications drawn from business and financial economics. The course is built around the statistical foundations and economic applications of the multiple regression model. Using statistical software, students will also learn how to conduct, present, and critique empirical research.
cmCourseInfo.title: Forecasting and Time Series Econometrics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 3-4hr online videos/week asynchronously.
The videos and lecture notes will be posted on Quercus.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week (Wednesdays 2-4) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
The online webinar will be held on Bb Collaborate.
Students need to have equipment that can access internet and can use Bb Collaborate, e.g. microphone.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to econometrics. Statistical foundations and the interpretation of multiple regression models, with an emphasis on cross-sectional data. Application of regressions to a wide variety of economic questions and data sources, including the use of statistical software. Problems in the identification of causality, and an introduction to methods of addressing common statistical issues
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Econometrics I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 3-4hr online videos/week asynchronously.
The videos and lecture notes will be posted on Quercus.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week (Wednesdays 10-12) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
The online webinar will be held on Bb Collaborate.
Students need to have equipment that can access internet and can use Bb Collaborate, e.g. microphone. In this course, we will use Stata to do empirical questions. I recommend Stata IC, version 15. Earlier versions are also admissible, but they may not be supported by the instructor or TA. Students can purchase Stata at discounted prices.
See https://mdl.library.utoronto.ca/technology/statistical-software for details.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course in applied microeconomics is concerned with the functioning of markets and the behaviour of firms within these markets. The focus is on strategic relationships between organizations, including competitive relationships among firms in the same market and cooperative relationships between a firm and its suppliers and distributors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Markets, Competition, and Strategy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate Ultra will be used.
This course will be online and in hybrid format.
Students will be given problem sets and quizzes and there will be online tutorials where the Teaching Assistant will discuss the answers.
Office hours will be held online every week.
The lecture notes are in pdfs and will be put on Quercus in advance.
Students would need a reliable internet connection (and microphone/webcam if they wish to interact in class).

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of selected material on compensation and incentives in organizations. Topics include recruitment and hiring, training, turnover, downsizing, motivating workers, teams, allocating authority and task assignment.
cmCourseInfo.title: Personnel Economics

courses.name: Competing Views in Macroeconomic Theory and Policy

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with a systematic analysis of competing perspectives on key areas of macroeconomic theory and policy. Special attention paid to competing views regarding key fiscal, monetary, and trade policy issues as applied to Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Competing Views in Macroeconomic Theory and Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ECO227Y1/(STA220H1, STA255H1)/(STA237H1, STA238H1)/(STA257H1, STA261H1); at least one FCE in ECO at the 300 level or higher.

cmCourseInfo.description: Seminars or workshops may be offered in one or more subjects each year. Students must meet the Prerequisites announced by the Department. (See the Undergraduate Administrator or the Economics Department website for details.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Note: Prerequisites: ECO358H1 NOTE: For Financial Economics Specialist students, this course may be used to fulfill the 3rd year or higher 1.0 FCE course list. Contact department for details.
Class is an online synchronous course.
Students will synch online with course instructor or TA three times a week on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 19:00 to 21:00.
During the course, the course instructor or TA will help to go over the course notes, answer student questions and discuss assignments.
There will also be random quiz questions issued online.
Zoom is the major application tool to broadcast live online course. Students do not have to install Zoom application, students will receive Zoom URL and password from QUERCUS to connect online. However, it is strongly recommend all students visit Zoom website(https://zoom.us) to create a free Zoom account and test your web camera, mic and speaker before the class starts. Ensue these devices working are essential for participation in the class.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the price, distribution, and growth theories of major economic thinkers before 1870, from pre-classical contributions by Aristotle, Mercantilists, and Physiocrats to the classical authors Adam Smith, David Ricardo, T.R. Malthus, and Karl Marx.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Economic Thought

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This online hybrid course will have most of the material posted for your access at any time but also requiring student's attending discussion groups and writing exams at specific times.
I will post detailed written lectures, course readings, and video overviews of my written lectures on our UofT Quercus site.
Students will also attend seminar discussion groups (ideally 2-3PM EST on Mondays and Wednesdays but we may alter these times to accommodate different time zones) and write exams at specific times through our webpage on Quercus.
Please note that everyone must write the exams simultaneously at the same EST time regardless of their location.
Students can also submit questions about the lectures that I will address in a Quercus discussion group from 3-4PM on Mondays and Fridays, which you may join live if you wish or look at later in your own time.
You need a computer and internet access but only to access the course on UofT's Quercus site.
